titleStmt.title: Three severall letters of great importance. The first, containing the brave exploits of the Lyme men at Axmister in Devonshire; together with a perfect list of the number of prisoners, ordnance, armes, and ammmuition [sic] taken there. The second, containing the late affaires at Duncanon Fort, and the city of Corke in Ireland, together with the conversion of one bishop and two deanes; shewing that they are willing to relinquish their pompe and great titles and to become single ministers againe. The third, concerning the late losse of Monmouth, and the possibility of regaining it. Passed according to order.

titleStmt.title: Three severall letters of great importance. The first, containing the brave exploits of the Lyme men at Axmister in Devonshire; together with a perfect list of the number of prisoners, ordnance, armes, and ammmuition [sic] taken there. The second, containing the late affaires at Duncanon Fort, and the city of Corke in Ireland, together with the conversion of one bishop and two deanes; shewing that they are willing to relinquish their pompe and great titles and to become single ministers againe. The third, concerning the late losse of Monmouth, and the possibility of regaining it. Passed according to order.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Three Severall LETTERS OF Great IMPORTANCE.
The Fir≈øt, containing the brave exploits of the Lyme men at Axmi≈øter in Devon≈øhire; Together with a perfect Li≈øt of the number of Pri≈øoners, Ordnance, Armes, and Ammmuition taken there.

The Second, containing the late Affaires at Duncanon Fort, and the City of Corke in Ireland, Together with the Conver≈øion of one Bi≈øhop, and two Deanes; Shewing that they are willing to relinqui≈øh their Pompe and great Titles and to become ≈øingle Mini≈øters againe.
The Third, concerning the late lo≈ø≈øe of Monmouth, and the po≈ø≈øibility of regaining it.
LONDON, Printed for G. B. Decemb. 6. 1644.

div.head: THREE LETTERS Of CONSEQVENCE, from LYME in Dor≈øet≈øhire, CORKE in Ireland, and MONMOVTH in South-Wales.

div.p:
AFter tender, of my be≈øt re≈øpects, I know you have a longing de≈øire to hear how this g ‚Ä¢ go in the≈øe parts, as wee much de≈øire to heare „Äà‚óä„Äâ you, „Äà‚óä„Äâ wee cannot enjoy you as formerly. For newes in the≈øe parts, viz. The 15. of this pre≈øent November, wee fell upon Axminster with our Hor≈øe and Foote, and, through Gods mercie, beat them off their Works, in≈øomuch that we were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Towne, and they betooke them to the Church which they had forrified, on which we were loath to ca≈øt our men, being we had a Garri≈øon to look on, My Brother and my ≈øelfe were both there, we fired part of the Town, what ≈øucce≈ø≈øe we had, you may reade by the particulars here inclo≈øed, we lo≈øt onely one man in the taking the Towne, and had five wounded. The Monday following we marched to Axmi≈øter againe,
Major Sydenbam having joyned with us that Lords day at night before, thinking to have ≈øeized on the Church, and tho≈øe forces that were in it, but finding them ≈øo ≈øtrong, as that is might indanger the lo≈ø≈øe of many of our men, wee thought is not fit to fall upon the Church, but rather to ≈øet the Hou≈øes on fire, that were not burnt in the fir≈øt firing, which accordingly we did, and burne downe the whole Towne, unle≈ø≈øe it were ≈øome few hou≈øes, but yet they would not come forth of the Church. The next day being Tue≈øday, we marched to Chedeock, thinking to have carried that Hou≈øe, and ≈øummoned them, but they refu≈øed to yeild, whereupon our Souldiers were all willing to ≈øtorme it, which we did, but we were forced to leave it, and lo≈øt in the ≈øtorming, nine killed, and ≈øeven wounded, and in the night marched to our Garri≈øon againe. Had we but 500. Hor≈øe, we ≈øhould, through Gods mercy, cleare all the Countrey. The Enemy hath ≈øince quitted Axmi≈øter Church, and Mourt-Hou≈øe, ≈øo that wee are at pre≈øent onely mole≈øted with tho≈øe at Chedeock-Hou≈øe, which we ≈øhould ea≈øily ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe, had we but five hundred Hor≈øe to cleare the Countrey of the Enemy, from falling in our Reare, for the Enemy lyeth at Chard with five hundred Hor≈øe and Foot, be≈øides tho≈øe that beleaguer Taunton Ca≈øtie, which is much admired at, that they being ≈øo long be≈øieged, which is now eight weekes, and no a≈øsi≈øtance: God ≈øtirre up the heares of tho≈øe that have the power in their hands to help them.

We have intelligence from Plimouth, that on Friday la≈øt, they were like to be betrayed by blowing up their Magazine, which thorough Gods mercie was prevented, and four of the Actors were hanged, but there is a Scotti≈øh Maior that had a hand in it, (as it ≈øuppo≈øed) who is either ≈øent up, or to be ≈øent. Grenvill was ready with five thou≈øand hor≈øe and foot to fall in at the very in≈øtant, when it was to be done, yet we may ≈øee how good our God is to us notwith≈øtanding our unworthyne≈ø≈øe. I am per≈øwaded the We≈øt may ea≈øily be regained if forces were ≈øent, and that tho≈øe Gentlemen thereunto belonging would but deny them≈øelves and ≈øet to the worke. The Sickne≈ø≈øe is cea≈øed in this place, I know not of one hath died this fortnight of the Feaver, it did raigne very hot a while.

Our men are in mi≈øerable condition for want of pay, and they mu≈øt have ≈øomething to buy them cloathes. It is pitty that Lyme ≈øhould be
quitted, and greater pitty ≈øo many men ≈øhould be lo≈øt for want of ≈øub≈øi≈øtance. If you know of any that may be a meanes of ≈øending reliefe to the Garri≈øon, I be≈øeech you that you would ≈øtirre in it, for if it be not ≈øpeedily relieved, we mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity quit the Garri≈øon.

The very day we tooke Axmi≈øter, it plea≈øed God through di≈øtre≈ø≈øe of weather to ≈øend us in a ≈øhip bound from Morlais in France to Tap≈øham neere Exce≈øter, laden with Linnen cloath which belongs to the Malignants of Exce≈øter, for the mo≈øt part I beleeve the goods, as neere as I can gue≈ø≈øe by the ≈øeverall letters and bills of lading that belong to the Enemy, will amount to three thou≈øand pound cleare of all charges

div.head: A Li≈øt of the Pri≈øoners taken and ≈ølaine at Axmi≈øter, Novemb. 15. 1644.
div.p:
LIeutenant Dugdale. Lieutenant Byam. Lieuten. Bydgood. Henry Bartus, Col. Cholmeleys man. William Knight, Sir Rebert Brets man. John Vyle, Henry Harly, Richard Stout. Lieut. Col. Paulets men. William Taylor, Hugh Dou≈øon, Major Hinckleys men. Richard short, Richard Walcome, John Iri≈øh, Alexander Pring, William Braford. Lieut, Col. Perciyes men. Antony Pargam, William Call, Willi. Bowyer, Rock. King. Major Percyes men. Samp≈øon Pickford, John Jacob, of Capt. Hen. Berkleys Troope. Joh. Barret, Lieu. Col. Raw≈øings man. George Randall of Capt. Ca-litons Company. Ambro≈øe Be≈øitha, Thomas An≈øte ‚Ä¢ s. Capt. Whibbyes men. John Gamon, of Capt. Southcotts Company. The Harris, Hugh Ebbens, of Capt. Slowleyes Company, George Cley, Andrew Skinner, William Smith, Robert Hodg≈øley, John Rodd. of Capt Yews Company. Will. Ellis, Rich Ellis, Rich. Rowell Will. Coles, Iohn Randall, of Capt. Manu ‚Ä¢ ks Company. Iohn Dudney, Iohn Palmer, Iohn Cotley, of Capt. Turners Company. Iohn Kent, Laur. Husband, Robert Husband, of Majors Sprats Company. Will Iones, Rich. Cornelis, of Capt Harris Company. Maurice Caudry, Timothy Palmer, of Capt. Kotolls Company Rich. Cornelis, Rob. Cawley, Lieut, Ducalfs Company. Nicholas Wright, Capt. Edward
Barkleys man. Robert Salter, Capt. Henry Berkleys man. Robert Starke, Robert Singent, Robert Dyer, of Lieut. Webbers Company.
In all 56. Pri≈øoners.

S ‚Ä¢ aire, Sir Richard Cholmeley Knight, Commander in Chiefe. Two Majors, one of them Major Hartley, with other Commanders and Officers, not knowne among≈øt the re≈øt, which were in all 30. Baronet Bret dangerou≈øly wounded.
Taken. 4. great Pieces of Ordnance. 150, Armes. 50. Hor≈øe. 3. Drums. 105. Halberts. 3. Barrells of Gunpowder.

div.head: A Letter from CORKE in Ireland ≈øpeaketh thus.
div.p:
A Sodaime and altogether unexpected opportunity of writing unto you offering it ≈øelfe, with much gladne≈ø≈øe I embrace the ≈øame, and according to this very little ≈øcantling of Time, ≈øhall endeavour to give you an account of my pre≈øent condition, and of the proceedings in the≈øe parts. The la≈øt I wrote was by a Mini≈øter to Captaine Moulton, who ≈øet ≈øaile out of Milford Haven in Wales, and was bound for England about the tenth of August la≈øt; I doubt not but tho≈øe lines inclo≈øed, to a Gentlewoman came to your hands, ≈øince that time our de≈øigne is changed, the Lord hath beene plea≈øed to di≈øpo≈øe other wayes of us, our Ship is hired by Captaine Richard Swanley Admirall of the Iri≈øh Seas, for the Service of the State, we were by him imployed the 20. of September, and pre≈øently ≈øent to Duncanon Ca≈øtle neere Waterford in Ireland, there we continued about thirty dayes, pa≈ø≈øing through many dangers, our Enemies lying on every ≈øide of us, ready to ≈øinke us by day, and fire us by night, if the Lord had not bin on our ≈øide we had bin de≈øtroyed: He who hath promi≈øed to be with his People when they pa≈ø≈øe thorough the waters, and walke through the fire, hath gratiou≈øly preferved us out of the mouthes of Lyons, for ≈øuch indeed are our implacable Enemies, who have left no ≈øtone unturned to worke our overthrow. They are Jri≈øh and Dunkerkers, who often have ≈øet ≈øayle in
darke nights, come up by us, and fired many Gunnes upon us, but ble≈ø≈øed be God we lo≈øt little on our parts, we have ≈øhot them thorough and through, but ≈øunke none of them as we know of yet; we had onely the Fort of Duncanon our freind, where I found the old Lord E≈ømund, who maintains the Fort with two hundred men, again≈øt the whole Province of Lin≈øter, my Lord of E≈ømund and his Chaplaine refu≈øe to take the Covenant, but the Captaine of the Ca≈øtle and all the Souldiers have freely taken it, I doubt not of their reality. They wanted victualls, bread, and pea≈øe, and my Captaine hath ≈øupplied them ≈øufficiently, untill more expected provi≈ø≈øions come to them from our Admirall in Milford-Haven.

From the River of Waterford, we came to the Harbour of Corke, Octob. 23. and the la≈øt Sabbath, by the de≈øire of my Captaine, I went in our Pinnace to the City of Corke, where through the importunity of my Lord Inchequin, I preached in the afternoone, on Monday morning my Lord furni≈øhed me with one of his Hor≈øes, and we rode together with the Governour of the City, to our Ship, riding then about twelve miles from Gorke, my Captaine entertayned my Lord very generou≈øly, and all his attendants, with variety of cheare and triumph, of firing Ordnance.

My Lord Inchequin hath given good te≈øtimonies of his reality to the Parliament in England, he hath about twelve hundred Souldi Souldiers, above ≈øixe hundred of them have taken the Covenant, the re≈øt mu≈øt, or el≈øe ≈øoone be ca≈øhiered the Army, all Papi≈øts, and almo≈øt all the Iri≈øh, are excluded the City; the Governour thereof, Captaine Bani≈øter, is a very hone≈øt godly man, who is a very great and good a≈øsi≈øtant to my Lord: I doubt not, but they will prove in≈øtruments of much good, in carrying on that noble and pious worke begun by them, in this poore, di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and bleeding Kingdome of Ireland.

The Hollanders have ≈øent three Ships laden with Provi≈øions to Corke, otherwi≈øe they might have fami≈øhed long ≈øince, they have received nothing as yet from the Parliament, I hope they will ≈øoone ≈øend a ≈øupply.

This Bearer, Captaine Walker, is imployed in this Expedition, by my Lord Inchequin, for this very purpo≈øe. My Captaine hath furni≈øhed Corke with ≈øeven Barrells of Powder, many Muskets, and other nece≈ø≈øaries, out of his owne Ship-≈øtore.

One thing is very remarkable in Corke: I found two hone≈øt Deanes, and an old Bi≈øhop, ≈øomwhat well-affected to the Parliament in England; the Deanes are well contented to loo≈øe their Titles, and the Bi≈øhop to be onely Ma≈øter Bi≈øhop, this is no ≈ømall wonder as I ≈øuppo≈øe.
We are at the fir≈øt opportunity of winde, to ≈øet Saile for Duncanon, and there to continue, as it is thought, for two or three Moneths.

This afternoone, there came a Ship into this Harbour from England, hath brought uewes, that the Earle of E≈ø≈øex had routed the Enemy, and pur≈øued them. I hope you will ≈øoone have a full end of the Wars in England, and that the Iri≈øh Rebells will be forced to feele the weight of our Engli≈øh Swords.

I have no further newes to acquaint you withall, there is a Ship, that within the≈øe ten dayes (if God permit) will ≈øee Saile for Port≈ømouth, then I intend to trouble you with a few lines. And for the pre≈øent I re≈øt,

closer.dateline: From my Study on Board the Ship Lewes, riding in the Harbour of Corke in Ireland, Novemb. 10. 1644.

div.head: The News from Monmouth is this.
div.p: Noble Captaine I know you expect newes, I allwayes told you, good or bad, you ≈øhould heare of it, as long as God ≈øends life and being.
Now as you have heard good, accept of what plea≈øed God, wee have lo≈øt Monmouth, a con≈øiderable place, and men of quality taken Pri≈øoners there, but no que≈øtion of redemption.

Our lo≈ø≈øe was 13. Peeces of Ordnance great and ≈ømall, powder and match, with bullets and great ≈øhot, but few men lo≈øt, nor above ≈øix on either ≈øide, in all I meane to that number, all re≈øting on the bed of ≈øecurity, and carele≈øne≈ø≈øe, God mend it, we are apt to
pre≈øume: to conclude it was a great lo≈ø≈øe, and a great griefe to the Governour, he being ab≈øent, and left a better Charge.
God ble≈ø≈øed me well being but four dayes before in the Towne, where I was mo≈øt forward in action and a man made choyce of for the over≈øeeing of the workes, which I did to my be≈øt endeavour.
I prai≈øe God I lo≈øt nothing but Oates for my hor≈øes, but I got by the hay, for I was two hundred ≈øtrong in Lice at the lea≈øt.
I was never in ≈øo ba≈øe a place in my dayes, I made a ≈øhire ≈øerve eight weekes, and dur≈øt not change, for Lice are mad at cleane Linnen.
Come, we are not daunted as yet, but by Gods good ble≈ø≈øing hope to recover all againe, but the waters are up there, and here to, ≈øo that there is no marching to doe good.
We mu≈øt waite Gods time, or the be≈øt man may faile of his skill, I feare pre≈øumption is and was our fauit, and I beleeve no le≈ø≈øe.
